payload.instructions:
## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: C:/Users/krkna/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: C:/Users/krkna/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

# AGENTS.md instructions for g:\MythologIQ\Hearthlink

<INSTRUCTIONS>
## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: C:/Users/krkna/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: C:/Users/krkna/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.
</INSTRUCTIONS>

# Context from my IDE setup:

## Active file: .agent/staging/PROMPT_AGENT_1_ROUTE_ANALYZER.txt

## Active selection of the file:
::: TRIBUNAL PROMPT (AGENT 1: ROUTE_ANALYZER - MODEL: Codex) :::

**YOUR ROLE:** Navigation Flow Analyzer
**ACTION REQUIRED:** âŒ ANALYSIS ONLY - NO CODE CHANGES

## TASK: Trace the Test-to-Component Navigation Path

### Step 1: Analyze Test Navigation
Read `tests/e2e/accessibility-comprehensive.spec.ts` lines 148-165 and answer:
1. What selector does the test use to find the Core module button?
2. What URL does it wait for after clicking?
3. What component renders at that URL?

### Step 2: Trace CoreDashboard Structure
Read `src/components/core/CoreDashboard.tsx` and answer:
1. Is it a tabbed interface or single-view?
2. Does KanbanBoard render immediately or require tab click?
3. Does RiskMatrix/GanttChart render immediately or require navigation?

### Step 3: Check ProjectsDashboard
Read `src/components/core/ProjectsDashboard.tsx` and answer:
1. Does this component render KanbanBoard, RiskMatrix, GanttChart?
2. Are they conditionally rendered (tabs, toggles)?
3. What `data-testid` attributes are present?

### Step 4: Verify Mock Data
Check `tests/e2e/mocks/mock-data-standard.ts` for:
1. Does `sampleProject()` scenario include risks?
2. Does it include projects with tasks?
3. Are there at least 3 items for each component to render?

### Deliverable:
A navigation flow diagram:
```
Test: page.goto('/') 
  â†’ Click [data-testid="module-core"]
  â†’ URL: /core
  â†’ Component: ???
  â†’ Subcomponent visible: ???
```

Plus: Root cause identification for why tests can't find components.

---
## ðŸ›‘ REQUIRED OUTPUT PROTOCOL (NON-NEGOTIABLE)

**Target File:** `.agent/staging/responses/AGENT_1_ROUTE_ANALYZER.md`

**Content:**
- `# REPORT: AGENT 1 (ROUTE_ANALYZER)`
- Navigation flow diagram
- Root cause analysis
- Recommended fix (test change OR component change)
- Status: [COMPLETE / PARTIAL / FAILED]

## Open tabs:
- PROMPT_AGENT_1_ROUTE_ANALYZER.txt: .agent/staging/PROMPT_AGENT_1_ROUTE_ANALYZER.txt
- AGENT_3_A11Y_FIXER.md: .agent/staging/responses/AGENT_3_A11Y_FIXER.md
- GanttChart.tsx: src/components/core/GanttChart.tsx
- AGENT_2_GOVERNANCE_LEAD.md: .agent/staging/responses/AGENT_2_GOVERNANCE_LEAD.md
- RiskMatrix.tsx: src/components/core/RiskMatrix.tsx

## My request for Codex:
::: TRIBUNAL PROMPT (AGENT 1: ROUTE_ANALYZER - MODEL: Codex) :::

**YOUR ROLE:** Navigation Flow Analyzer
**ACTION REQUIRED:** âŒ ANALYSIS ONLY - NO CODE CHANGES

## TASK: Trace the Test-to-Component Navigation Path

3. What component renders at that URL?

### Step 2: Trace CoreDashboard Structure

2. Does KanbanBoard render immediately or require tab click?
3. Does RiskMatrix/GanttChart render immediately or require navigation?

### Step 3: Check ProjectsDashboard
Read `src/components/core/ProjectsDashboard.tsx` and answer:

2. Are they conditionally rendered (tabs, toggles)?
3. What `data-testid` attributes are present?

### Step 4: Verify Mock Data
Check `tests/e2e/mocks/mock-data-standard.ts` for:

2. Does it include projects with tasks?
3. Are there at least 3 items for each component to render?


payload.text:
**Clarifying mock data and test issues**

Iâ€™m sorting out that the mock-data-standard.ts file doesnâ€™t include the sampleProject scenario or risks; those come from tauri-commandsâ€™ mocks. I see sampleProject there has fewer items than expected and no risks, which might cause test failures. It looks like tests assume ProjectsDashboard components show by default under /core, but actually, they require navigating to specific tabs or routes. The test likely uses outdated selectors and misses navigating properly. I plan to draft a report recommending updating test navigation or adjusting component rendering for better test stability.

summary.text:
**Clarifying mock data and test issues**

Iâ€™m sorting out that the mock-data-standard.ts file doesnâ€™t include the sampleProject scenario or risks; those come from tauri-commandsâ€™ mocks. I see sampleProject there has fewer items than expected and no risks, which might cause test failures. It looks like tests assume ProjectsDashboard components show by default under /core, but actually, they require navigating to specific tabs or routes. The test likely uses outdated selectors and misses navigating properly. I plan to draft a report recommending updating test navigation or adjusting component rendering for better test stability.

payload.name: shell_command
payload.arguments:
{"command":"@'
# REPORT: AGENT 1 (ROUTE_ANALYZER)

Navigation flow diagram
```
Test: page.goto('/')
  â†’ Click [data-testid="module-core"] (fallback: button name /core/i)
  â†’ URL: /core (waitForURL(/.*core.*/))
  â†’ Component: CoreDashboard (rendered by HearthlinkApp for /core)
  â†’ Subcomponent visible: CoreDashboard Overview tab (ProjectsDashboard not mounted)
```

Root cause analysis
- Selector mismatch: test uses `data-testid="module-core"`, but HearthlinkApp renders nav buttons as `data-testid="nav-module-core"` so the primary selector can fail.
- Wrong view for expectations: `/core` renders CoreDashboard with `activeTab = 'overview'`, so ProjectsDashboard (and Kanban/Risk/Gantt) are not rendered until the Projects tab is selected.
- Projects subviews are route-driven: Kanban/Risk/Gantt render only when the URL is `/core/projects/kanban`, `/core/projects/risks`, or `/core/projects/gantt` (or user clicks those tabs).
- Mock data gap: `Mocks.scenarios.sampleProject()` (from `tests/e2e/mocks/tauri-commands.ts`) seeds 1 project, 2 tasks, 2 kanban cards, and **no risks**, so RiskMatrix and Gantt may have nothing to render; it also does not guarantee 3+ items.
- `tests/e2e/mocks/mock-data-standard.ts` does not define `sampleProject()`; its standard data includes tasks/projects but no risks or kanban cards for Core dashboards.

Recommended fix (test change OR component change)
- Test change: click `data-testid="nav-module-core"` (or navigate directly), then navigate to `/core/projects/kanban` or click the Projects tab + Kanban tab before asserting Kanban/Risk/Gantt elements; update mocks to include risks + 3+ items if those components require data.
- Component change alternative: add `data-testid="module-core"` to the Core nav button and/or default CoreDashboard to Projects tab in test mode to render ProjectsDashboard on `/core`.

Status: COMPLETE
'@ | Set-Content -Path .agent/staging/responses/AGENT_1_ROUTE_ANALYZER.md","workdir":"g:\MythologIQ\Hearthlink"}

Exit code: 0
Wall time: 0.3 seconds
